data.text: Cyclist's Palsy on Long-Distance Bike Tours
Hi all. Anyone here deal with cyclist’s palsy? My hands went numb on day 2 and I’m trying to decide if I need to quit in order for them to improve. I have 5 days left.

I did. Had it really bad to point I could grip or move fingers properly. I went to am osteopath who massaged it and told me to do some stretches. Noticed an improvement immediately. Now if I feel it coming on I stretch on the bike. Maybe try Google the stretches and see if it helps. Also take a quick look at bike fit to make sure your not carrying too much weigh on hands. Funnily enough another thing I've noticed is padded fingerless gloves make it worse for me. Don't know whether the padding just presses in the wrong place but I feel it coming on when wearing then. Don't seem to get it with unpadded winter gloves or when not wearing any gloves

data.text:
Biker's palsy is no joke. I had it on a 6 day ride through Taiwan. Is there a stop at a bike shop that can help you with bar ends and a flat hand grip or a butterfly handlebar that will allow you to sit upright? Can you take a beat and get a bike fit? You have got to be able to take pressure off of your ulnar nerve, which is responsible for feeling in your pinkies to middle finger and your radial nerve which provides feeling to your thumb through middle finger. Use fascia release massage and decompress your wrist and elbow daily. Neural flossing can help do this. https://youtu.be/wlEdbGxAF4A. But really, if you can't get a better fit on your bike, it isn't going to get better.
Radial Nerve Flossing

data.text: interesting. I stumbled onto an exercise similar to this that I do while riding that helps to reduce the numbness in my hand an upper arm. Essentially, I bring my arm, hand palm down all the way back and raised as far as I can (picture a bowler as they would draw back before their forward motion). Then bring the arm straight forward (again like a bowler) turning the palm up as you come forward and closing it loosely into a fist as you bring your arm in at the elbow as if you were doing a curl in weight lifting. I do this several times with each arm and it alleviates the strain and numbness for a good while.

data.text: Too bad. This advice is going to sound trite but really all of the advice so far is saying the same thing - do something different. Change the fit of the bike, change body positions, wear looser gloves, wear more padded gloves, etc. I would say I am never in the same position on the bike more than 5 minutes so I might be an extreme. Are your arms bent slightly at all times? Is your body pushed too far forward because your seat is too far back or your handle bars too low? Are you resting your hands and not gripping the bars too tightly? I would keep going and try to change things up and take breaks every 1/2 hour until I figured it out. First thing for me is to make sure my body position allows my arms to be slightly bent while I am in a comfortable tilt. If your arms are not bent adjust your handlebars back or seat forward/lower (or both) until they are bent. You might not have an adjustable stem on the handlebars so you might have to rely on the seat changes. I would keep trying minor changes for short periods.
